title: Determine the net force acting on a slowing cart

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A cart of width <math alttext="w equals 13 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M equals 300 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves horizontally on a flat track. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of the cart is directly underneath a spout that begins emptying sand into the cart at a rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, measured in <math alttext="kilogram per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The distance that the cart has traveled is shown in the graph as a function of time from the instant that the sand begins to empty into the cart until sand no longer enters the cart. The graph also shows the line tangent to the distance function at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and another tangent line at time <math alttext="t equals 6 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.The wheels of the cart roll without slipping. (a) What is the rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which sand is emptied into the cart? Explain how you arrived at your answer.

frqParts.text: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A cart of width <math alttext="w equals 13 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="M equals 300 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves horizontally on a flat track. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of the cart is directly underneath a spout that begins emptying sand into the cart at a rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, measured in <math alttext="kilogram per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kg/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The distance that the cart has traveled is shown in the graph as a function of time from the instant that the sand begins to empty into the cart until sand no longer enters the cart. The graph also shows the line tangent to the distance function at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and another tangent line at time <math alttext="t equals 6 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.The wheels of the cart roll without slipping. (a) What is the rate <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which sand is emptied into the cart? Explain how you arrived at your answer.

A student analyzing the situation writes the equation <math alttext="v of t, equals 9 divided by t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>/</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to model the speed that the cart has as a function of time starting at <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and ending at the time that the left edge of the cart passes under the spout.(b) Identify one feature of the function <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> above that correctly models the motion of the cart. Justify your answer.

(c) Identify one feature of the function <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> above that incorrectly models the motion of the cart. Justify your answer.

The student fixes their mistakes and correctly derives an equation for <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.(d) The student wonders whether the net force acting on the cart is increasing or decreasing in magnitude as time passes. How could the student use the correct function <math alttext="v of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to make this determination?

The cart has completely passed from underneath the spout and encounters an incline that curves upwards. A student taking data obtains a function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for the distance traveled by the cart while it rises up the incline, where <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is when the cart is at the bottom of the incline.(e) Explain how the student could use the function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the change in vertical height of the cartâ€™s center of mass when the cart has traveled <math alttext="100 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> up the incline.

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
